title: Preparation and Purification of Active Recombinant Human Pancreatic Lipase in Escherichia coli
procedures:
This procedure to prepare recHPL includes five steps: (A) construction of expression plasmid, (B) expression in E. coli, (C) isolation, (D) refolding, and (E) purification.Construction of HPL expression plasmidST II-fused recHPL was cloned into the pASK-IBA3plus plasmid to allow expression in E. coli. The construct contains a C-terminal Strep-tag II to facilitate separation of recHPL (Figure 1). imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190628/20190628033807_7604.jpgFigure 1. Sequence of recHPL. A. Part of the nucleotide sequence of an HPL-pASK-IBA3plus plasmid and the deduced amino acid sequence. The entire sequence of HPL was confirmed using an autosequencer. Boxed region: the coding sequence of HPL, wavy underlines: the sequence of the linker, dotted underlines: the sequence of the ST II-tag. B. Structure of pASK-IBA 3Plus-HPL plasmid.Following the PCR protocol detailed below, amplify the coding sequence of HPL using the human pancreas cDNA library, Human MTC Panel I as the template for PCR using a Zymoreactor II (ATTO) thermal cycler with following conditions:[Primers]Primer 1 (forward), 5′-AAAGAAGTTTGCTACGAAAGACTC-3′Primer 2 (reverse), 5′-GATTGTGCCACACTCCCACTCG-3′[Reaction mixture]imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190628/20190628033923_1776.jpg[PCR conditions]table:

Purify the sequencing reactions using a BigDye TerminatorTM Purification Kit.Digest the amplicon 2 μl by adding FastDigest® Eco31I 1 μl, 10x FastDigest Green Buffer 2 μl, and ddH2O 15 μl at 37 °C for 5 min.Digest pASK-IBA3Plus 2 μl by adding FastDigest® Eco31I 1 μl, 10x FastDigest Green Buffer 2 μl, and ddH2O 15 μl at 37 °C for 5 min.Separate the digested samples by agarose gel electrophoresis using 1% agarose gel.Cut out the DNA bands (expected sizes of insert DNA and pASK-IBA3Plus are 1,350 bp and 3,247 bp, respectively) on the gel and purify with Wizard® SV Gel and PCR Clean-Up.Ligate the digested insert DNA with the digested pASK-IBA3plus to obtain an HPL-pASK-IBA3plus plasmid by DNA Ligation Kit, Ligation high Ver.2.Sequence all constructed plasmids using the Prism 3100 Avant sequencer to confirm the sequences of the designed recombinant HPLs. Use the following primers:Primer 7 (forward), 5′-CCCAGCAGAACCTTGCTTTCAGG-3′ Primer 8 (reverse), 5′-CTTCCCAGATTCCGTCTATGTCC-3′ Expression of recHPL in E. coliTransform 5 μl (10-fold dilution) of HPL-pASK-IBA3plus plasmid (ca. 2.5 ng) into 50 μl of E. coli DH5α competent cells in a 1.5 ml tube.Incubate for 30 min on ice.Incubate at 42 °C for 45 s.Add 900 μl of LB medium and culture at 37 °C for 1 h.Plate 100 μl of transformants on LB agar plates including 100 μg/ml ampicillin at 37 °C for 18 h.Pick up a single colony and grow the transformants in 5 ml LB medium including 100 μg/ml ampicillin in a 50 ml tube at 37 °C for 18 h.Transfer the bacterial suspension (3 ml) into 300 ml fresh LB medium including 100 μg/ml ampicillin in a shaking flask and culture for 3 h at 37 °C at 150 rpm.

Add 30 μl of 2 mg/ml anhydrotetracycline at a final concentration of 200 μg/L when the absorbance of the culture measured at 550 nm by a spectrophotometer (DeNovix) has reached 0.5 to induce expression of recombinant protein.Incubate for 5 h at 30 °C with shaking at 120 rpm.Centrifuge at 6,100 x g for 15 min at 4 °C using a high speed centrifuge (Hitachi) to harvest cells.Discard the supernatant, resuspend the bacterial pellet in 15 ml of buffer A, and freeze at -80 °C in a 50 ml tube until use.Isolation of recHPLThaw the frozen bacterial pellet.Lyse the bacterial cell pellet by sonication for 2 min (30 s x 4 times, output: 4, duty cycle: 70%) on ice. Centrifuge at 4,400 x g for 15 min at 4 °C using a high speed centrifuge (Hitachi).Discard the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 15 ml of lysis buffer.Centrifuge at 28,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.Discard the supernatant and wash the pellet twice with 30 ml of buffer A.Centrifuge at 28,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.Discard the supernatant and solubilize the washed inclusion bodies with 10 ml of buffer A* with agitation for 30 min at 4 °C. Add 50 μl of 2 M DTT at a final concentration of 10 mM to the supernatant.Incubate for 1 h at 37 °C with agitation at 100 rpm.Dilute the solubilized proteins with 10 ml of buffer A*.Dialyze against 150 ml of the equivalent buffer using the dialysis membrane (pore diameter = 50 Å) at 4 °C for 2 h to remove urea in a glass beaker with gentle stirring using a magnetic stirrer.Centrifuge the dialyzed solution at 28,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C. Aspirate the supernatant and transfer it to a 50 ml tube.

Add 20 ml of ice-cold equivalent buffer to the 2 ml of Strep-Tactin-Sepharose in a polystyrene column using a Pasteur pipette.Remove the equilibrated Strep-Tactin-Sepharose and add to the dialyzed protein solution in the 50 ml tube.Incubate at 4 °C for 30 min with gentle shaking at around 30 rpm.Pack the suspension mixture of Strep-Tactin-Sepharose into a polystyrene column.Wash with 20 ml of equivalent buffer at a flow rate of 3 drops/s, collecting 70-drop fractions using a fraction collector at 4 °C (Figure 2).Elute ST II-fused recHPL with elution buffer at a flow rate of 10 drops/s, collecting 22-drop fractions using a fraction collector at 4 °C.Measure the absorbance of 200 μl of fractions using 96-well microplates, a microplate spectrophotometer (DS Pharma Biomedical), and software Gen 5 at 280 nm at room temperature.Combine fractions with high A280 readings corresponding to the eluted protein and store the eluted peak fractions in a 15 ml tube at -80 °C. imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190628/20190628035147_2290.jpgFigure 2. Separation of recHPL by Strep-Tactin-Sepharose column. A. Affinity chromatography profile on a Strep-Tactin-Sepharose column (Schmidt et al., 1996). Elution was started from the fraction indicated by the arrow, and the peak was obtained at elution volume 19-26 ml. Column volume: 1.9 ml (i.e., 7 mm x 50 mm), flow rate: 10 s/drop, temperature: 4 °C. B. SDS-PAGE and Western blot analysis of the recHPL-ST II. From left lane, “CBB” shows a CBB-stained 12% polyacrylamide gel. “Anti-HPL” shows an electroblotted PVDF membrane blocked with 3% BSA and stained using the primary antibody, anti-lipase antibodies (1:3,000) at room temperature for 1 h and the secondary antibody, HRP-conjugated goat anti-rabbit antibodies (1:5,000) at room temperature for 1 h followed by developed using ECL reagent (GE Healthcare). 1, Marker proteins; 2, solubilized protein from inclusion body; 3 and 4, recHPL-ST II purified on the Strep-Tactin-Sepharose column.

Refolding of RecHPL (Figure 3)imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190628/20190628035515_0270.jpgFigure 3. Procedure for refolding of isolated recHPL Thaw the frozen eluted peak fractions and measure the absorbance at 280 nm at room temperature.Add urea to a final concentration of 8 M to 7-12 ml of the purified 0.1-0.2 mg/ml recHPL in peak fractions.Add 2 M DTT to a final concentration of 10 mM.Incubate for 2 h at 37 °C with agitation at approximately 100 rpm.Dialyze against 300 ml of refolding buffer containing a step-wise decrease in urea concentration (6 M and 4 M) at 4 °C for 2 h.Dialyze against 300 ml of refolding buffer containing 2 M urea at 4 °C overnight.Dialyze against 300 ml of refolding buffer containing step-wise decrease in urea concentration (1 M and 0.5 M) at 4 °C for 2 h.Dialyze against 300 ml of refolding buffer containing 0 M urea at 4 °C for 1 h.Centrifuge at 21,000 x g for 5 min and collect the supernatant to remove protein aggregates at 4 °C.Purification of recHPL (Figure 4)Note: Store all reagents and carry out all procedures at 4 °C. Add the supernatant of the refolded recHPL to an AmiconTM Bioseparations Stirred Cell with an ultrafiltration disc (10 kDa NMWL).Concentrate recHPL by 2-10 times using the stirred cell.Filter the concentrated recHPL through the GL chromatodisc 0.45 μm (GL Science, 25N)Filter the running buffer for FPLC through a cellulose acetate membrane filter, 0.45 μm.Inject 1 ml of refolded recHPL into a HiPrep 16/60 Sephacryl S-200 HR column (column volume: 120 ml), pre-equilibrated with running buffer on an AKTA Purifier FPLC system at a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min.Elute the column with 180 ml of running buffer at a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min, collecting 2 ml fractions.

Measure the absorbance of fractions at 280 nm and store approximately 5 fractions (each 2 ml) of the second peak as active recHPL.Determine the lipolytic activity of recHPL using tributyrin as substrate by automated titration of fatty acids released with 10 mM NaOH using the pH-stat AT-510 (Kawaguchi et al., 2018). imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20190628/20190628035403_4175.jpgFigure 4. Purification of active recHPL by gel-filtration FPLC. Elution profile of recHPL on size exclusion. RecHPL after refolding was loaded onto a HiPrep 16/60 Sephacryl S-200 column (column volume: 120 ml) and eluted using 10 mM TBS containing 400 mM L-Arg at a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min at 4 °C. Protein peaks were detected by measuring absorbance at 280 nm using a UPC-900 monitor and AKTA Purifier. Active recHPL-ST II (1.8-6 mg) was obtained from 1 L of culture, and it showed a specific activity of 1.2-1.9 kU/mg. Specific activity of the fractions was measured using 0.11 M tributyrin emulsified in 1 ml reaction buffer as the substrate. The measurements were performed containing colipase in excess, 0.5 μg/50 μl. After addition of each fraction eluted by gel filtration FPLC in Figure 4 (0.5 μg/50 μl), the NaOH consumption was recorded at a reaction temperature of 37 °C using the automatic potentiometric titrator, pH-stat AT-510 (Kyoto Electronics Manufacturing Co. Ltd.). One unit was defined as the amount of enzyme that released 1.0 μmol of free fatty acid per min.
